Out of curiosity, does anyone know how this works in NEAT/HyperNEAT at the
moment? 

How does it break ties, especially with regard to the generation champion
(when elitism is on)?


Cheers,
Jeff Clune

Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University

jclune@...




> From: <tansey@...>
> Reply-To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Date: Mon, 25 May 2009 13:55:25 -0400
> To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>, Colin Green
> <colin.green1@...>
> Cc: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Subject: Re: [neat] Re: CfP: IEEE Symposium on Computational Intelligence and
> Games
> 
> Quoting Colin Green <colin.green1@...>:
> 
>> 2009/5/25 Julian Togelius <julian@...>:
>>> 
>>> Another example: Just last week at CEC we discussed the simple but
>>> powerful idea that you should scramble your population before sorting
>>> (or use a non-order-preserving sorting algorithm) in a normal
>>> Evolution Strategy to encourage exploitation of neutrality in the
>>> search space.
>> 
>> If I'm understanding you correctly then I think the fairly standard
>> technique (AFAIK) of roulette wheel selection  effectively does this
>> anyway.
>> 
>> Colin
>> 
> 
> 
> Roulette wheel though would be an overly aggressive non-deterministic
> selection
> function. I think what Julian is referring to is much simpler. If you have a
> list of individuals sorted in best-first order, then an order-preserving
> sorting algorithm would prefer the older individuals over newer ones in the
> case of a tie. I think the hypothesis here is that if you have a big plateau
> then you should randomly pick between the older/newer individuals that are
> tying, because it allows the algorithm to spread out its search; even if it's
> effectively doing a random walk at that point. If the same individual keeps
> spawning children each generation (assuming a Gaussian mutation with a fixed
> sigma that's small relative to the plateau) then your search will potentially
> get stuck.
> 
> Wesley
